Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SHINE: Laboratory, Observational, and Modeling Investigations of the Torus Instability and Associated Solar Corona Eruptive Phenomena
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will extend understanding of solar corona plasmas beyond what is possible using single approaches, such as just analyzing data, just modeling, or just doing experiments. The cross-checking and discussion of these different approaches will provide a robust means for getting to the heart of the matter and finding out what is really going on. By reconciling first-principle models, experiments, and analysis of observations, there is an excellent prospect of achieving long-sought insights and improved understanding regarding underlying solar eruption mechanisms. This 3-year collaborative SHINE project would yield: (i) improved understanding of solar corona global phenomena since eruptions impact the remainder of the solar corona by shedding magnetic energy, magnetic helicity, and plasma particles; (ii) improved understanding of phenomena associated with eruptions such as energetic particles and electromagnetic radiation spanning from radio waves to gamma rays; (iii) improved understanding of the terrestrial impact of eruptions such as the effects on the magnetosphere and ionosphere, on radio propagation, and on spacecraft; (iv) increased public interest in solar physics, because of the highly visual nature of the experiments, the observations, and the numerical modeling; and, (v) training of students in solar and plasma physics and supporting a young female researcher. The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

The main goal of this 3-year collaborative SHINE project is to combine laboratory experiments, analysis of data from actual solar eruptions, and numerical modeling of the fundamental magnetohydrodynamics (MHD). Laboratory plasmas having morphology and dynamics similar to solar plasmas will be studied by at Caltech. This study is feasible because MHD has no intrinsic scale so MHD laboratory plasmas having dimensionless numbers and morphology similar to the solar corona will exhibit similar behavior, but on much different temporal and spatial scales. The analysis of actual solar eruptions and CME kinematics will be performed at the New Jersey Institute of Technology. This analysis will focus on the magnetic field structural properties in and above the source regions of eruptions. The analysis will apply non-linear force-free extrapolations based on magnetogram data obtained from spacecraft, such as Hinode and SDO, so as to calculate the strapping field profile as a function of altitude and core magnetic field. The dependence of CME acceleration profile and final speed on the decay index will be analyzed and compared to the experiments and to the numerical models developed at Predictive Science Inc. The project team will compare numerical predictions to both the laboratory experiments and the solar eruption analysis. This comparison will take into account both the strapping field decay index and morphological changes of erupting flux ropes due to kinking.

POR.DRECONTENT:
High resolution telescope and spacecraft images show that the surface of the sun contains complex, continuously-changing arch-shaped structures. These structures, called coronal loops, are  composed of hot, ionized gas that is embedded in magnetic fields. The ionized gas is called  plasma and is nearly perfectly attached to the magnetic field so that the plasma and magnetic field move in unison. This  motion is such that an arched plasma loop may sit still for hours or days and then suddenly erupt in a few minutes.

The general behavior of plasma embedded in a magnetic field is described by magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), a combination of electromagnetic and hydrodynamic theory.  MHD shows how magnetic forces push a plasma around and, at the same time, currents and magnetic fields in the plasma create these forces. An interesting feature is that MHD has no intrinsic scale so the same MHD model can equally describe a ten centimeter long  magnetized plasma or a plasma  that is a hundred million meters long. The time scale would differ for the two different size scales but the behavior would be qualitatively the same.

MHD is based on two fundamental ideas. The first is that parallel electric currents mutually attract.  An immediate consequence is that antiparallel currents mutually repel and together with the original idea, this  explains why opposite polarity magnetic poles attract while same polarity poles mutually repel.

The second idea is that a hot plasma behaves as if it has zero electrical resistance. This idea can be extended to show that the magnetic field is effectively frozen into the plasma which thus behaves like a superconductor. The magnetic field and plasma must move together because if not, there would be a time changing magnetic field in the plasma frame. Such a time-changing magnetic field would imply an electric field in the plasma, thereby violating the assumption of zero resistivity.

The research program at Caltech led by Paul Bellan exploits the above MHD concepts to produce centimeter scale plasmas that mimic the behavior of billion times larger erupting solar corona loops. Instead of being hundreds of millions meters long and taking hours or minutes to evolve, the lab plasmas evolve in microseconds. It has long been a mystery why plasma loops stay quiescent for a long time and then suddenly erupt. A model, called the Torus Instability, had been recently proposed to explain this. According to the Torus Instability, an externally generated additional magnetic field straps the plasma loop down, much like the metal straps on a wooden barrel hold the barrel together against internal pressure. However, if the plasma expands sufficiently, it can enter a region where the strapping field weakens in which case the plasma is no longer held down and so erupts.

 

The Caltech group constructed a carefully-tailored strapping magnetic field that held down an arched plasma when there was only a modest electric current flowing along the arch. However, when the electric current flowing along the arch increased and so produced strong forces that tended to make the arch expand, it was observed that after a brief time, the arch would break through the region of strong strapping field and then accelerate rapidly. This “bursting through the bonds” behavior was in good agreement with the Torus Instability. The loop behavior was diagnosed by both high-speed movies and electrical measurements and was studied for a range of strapping fields. The advantage of the lab experiment is that it is both controllable and reproducible so that the same situation can be investigated over and over again until understood.

In addition to the investigations of the Torus Instability, the Caltech group has examined other plasma behaviors relevant to solar and space physics. These include studies of magnetic reconnection, the process by which plasma can become unfrozen from the magnetic field. Reconnection is important for describing how a chunk of plasma breaks off during eruption and also for understanding how energetic particles are created during an eruption.

Because of their complexity, plasmas are rich in wave phenomena. Spacecraft measure oscillating magnetic fields presumed to be certain types of plasma waves.  However, without knowing the wavelength of the waves, it is impossible to tell whether the observed signal is a wave or simply the spacecraft moving through a static undulating field, like a car going over a washboard road. Paul Bellan has shown how the wavelength of certain waves can be measured using just a single spacecraft. This contrasts with previous methods which required multiple spacecraft. The new technique involves combining information from magnetic fields and electric currents and  has  recently been  successfully demonstrated on the spacecraft comprising the Magnetosphere Multiscale mission.
